import React, { Component } from "react"; import 'react-quill/dist/quill.snow.css'; import { Segment, Grid, Header, List, Form, Button, Progress } from "semantic-ui-react"; import Nav from "../../components/shared/Nav"; import SubNav from "./SubNav"; import Editor from "./componentFour/editor"; import "../shared/layout.css"; // import _ from 'lodash' class AgilePage extends Component { constructor(props) { super(props); this.state = {}; this.handleItemClick = this.handleItemClick.bind(this); } handleItemClick = (e, { name }) => this.setState({ activeItem: name }) render() { return (
Current Progress
{/* Part 1 */}
General Introduction

The main objective of this module is to enable participants to experience the challenges of problem-solving and innovation through an agile, flexible and team-based approach.

At the end of the module, participants would be able

Experience the context of challenges in the work environment, resolve at least one problem and suggest an innovation or prototype solution to overcome the problem. Use the vehicle of empathy, person-centred and lean management approaches to understand stakeholdersâ€™ interests in solving the problem. {/* part 2 */}
Describe your Job Description?

Identify the purpose of your role, key tasks, and main accountabilities of your job.

Submit
{/* part 3 */}
Illustrate the main processes of your job from an input, throughput, output and collaboration point of view.

Identify the key inputs you need to make to complete your tasks, the transformation system of the work done, and the outputs or results you expect to achieve in your job. Explain how you need to work with others to completed particular work assignments. You may use and input-throughput-output diagram to illustrate your key points.

Submit
{/* part 4 */}
Choose a particular aspect, assignment or project of your job where it is possible to bring about improvement or innovation on your job.

You may describe particular bottlenecks, which you encounter: refer to relevant aspects of the input-throughput-output diagram. The bottlenecks may arise as there may be a need to increase speed, have a more efficient process, reduce waste to create value, etc. from existing resources.

Submit
{/* part 5 */}
What is the improvement or innovation you want to bring about in your job?

Give the rationale of the innovation you want to introduce as a means of applying information, imagination and initiative to derive solutions to the problem at hand.

Submit
{/* part 6 */}
Use lean management such as a Fish-Bone Diagrams to elaborate on the issues surrounding the problem.

Use A3 thinking to understand the problem: see extract of article below that was adapted from the web on 21.5.2020.
Extract from: https://kanbanize.com/lean-management/improvement/a3-problem-solving https://kanbanize.com/lean-management/improvement/a3-problem-solving

What is A3 Thinking?

First of all, letâ€™s briefly touch upon the mindset that A3 thinking aims to develop. It can be summarized in 7 elements:

Logical Thinking â€“ A3 represents a step-based thinking process. Presenting information in an objective way â€“ there are no hidden agendas here. Results and Processes â€“ sharing what end results were achieved as well as the means of achieving them. Sharing only essential information and putting it into a visual format whenever possible. Whatever actions are taken, they must be aligned with the companyâ€™s strategy and objectives. The focus is on developing a consistent perspective that can be adapted across the entire organization. The focus is on developing a consistent perspective that can be adapted across the entire organization.
Origin of the A3 Problem-Solving Tool

The A3 report is one of the many Lean management tools, developed as part of the Toyota Production System (TPS).

There isnâ€™t a single inventor of the A3 reporting method. In fact, Isao Kato (former manager at Toyota) describes it as a hybrid between the PDCA cycle and Toyotaâ€™s philosophy to make things visible.

There is also a legend that Taiichi Ohno often refused to read further than the first page of any written report. This is why the A3 is a one-page report. The name A3 simply comes from the European A3 paper size corresponding to 11-inches by 17-inches or 29.7cm x 42cm.

The A3 thinking played a major role in Toyotaâ€™s commercial success. Consequently, it became a widespread tool, now used in various industries.

This is why the whole organization should be familiar with the concept of lean thinking and be prepared to assists at any time. Sometimes this is challenging, but it can show how flexible an organization really is.

At the end of the day, the active communication between all parties involved is crucial for the success of any A3 project.

The A3 Report

The A3 report is a single-page document, which reflects the results of the whole process. Usually, it contains seven steps, but it may also have other variations. Below you can find an A3 report example which most often will include the following steps:

Background/Clarify the problem Current situation Set targets/goals Root cause analysis Countermeasures Implementation Effect confirmation/Follow-up
Issues Surrounding the Problem
Submit
{/* part 7 */}
Report on how each of these actors define the innovation exercise.

Describe the problem from each of the actorâ€™s point of view and their accompanying rationale and interests.

Submit
{/* part 8 */}
Empathise and search for solutions.

Respond to the interests of the various actors. Collaborate with the various actors to search for solutions. List several possible solutions and recommend the most appropriate solution for the actors.

Submit
{/* part 9 */}
Assess the risks to implement the recommended solutions.

Take into account the issues of business/operational uncertainty, technical uncertainty and environmental uncertainty that may affect your recommended solution. State your comments here.

Submit
{/* part 10 */}
Test solutions your most appropriate prototype solution.

Explain the challenges and problems of implementation.

Submit
{/* part 11 */}
Evaluate the success of your initiative

Does the innovation meet on objectives? Meet on requirements? Meet on schedule? Meet on budget? Is sustainable in approach? Is agile in approach? You may make your comments on a cost-benefit analysis.

Submit
); } } export default AgilePage;
